Text_Numeracy: As an intern in a busy nutrition clinic, I was often responsible for checking patients' blood sugar levels. One day, I was checking the levels of an elderly woman suffering from diabetes. She had some other health issues as well, in particular, poor vision. After checking her blood sugar levels, I noticed they were abnormally low. While talking to her about it, I also found that she was dyslexic and likely unable to read the label on her packs of glucose tablets. I confirmed all this with her, then went to staff and reported it to them. The staff then brought the woman into the office before her evaluation visit so they could meet with her and educate her about her medications.

Text_Numeracy: A few days after recovering from viral conjunctivitis, I paid a visit to a friend's house to catch up and spend some time with her outside of work. I had been out of town for her birthday the month prior and wanted to see her in person and give her a birthday gift I had picked up on my travels. During my visit, she began coughing uncontrollably and I noticed that she was having difficulty breathing. I checked her heart rate and asked her a few questions. She had been tested for Covid earlier in the week and had been given the all clear, but I wanted to check and see if she was having an allergic reaction to her environment (she has a dog and we were sitting on the couch), so I checked in and made sure she wasn't taking any allergy meds. After ruling out an allergic reaction and suggesting looking for any possible allergens or irritants in her space, we decided to call an ambulance to be safe.

Text_TrustPhys:
I've been with my physician for several years now. We've formed a relationship where he trusts me to be honest about everything; I've never felt uncomfortable when discussing anything with him. 

The front office staff didn't have great service at first, but it has improved. Since the physician has improved quite a bit and was pretty attentive to our requests for changes, I'm inclined to trust him. 

Our needs are met during a typical exam; lab work is typically ordered at least once a year and anything else that may be necessary (exam or lab) is done on a regular basis. 

Sometimes labs are returned with no explanation as to what the results are; that could use some improvement. Little explanations for the results would be helpful rather than just "you don't have ____". 

Overall, we are satisfied with our care and physician.

Text_SubjectiveLit: I am quite adept at obtaining, processing, and understanding basic health information and services. My formal education allows me to think critically and analyze information regarding my health and the health of others.

Text_Numeracy: One experience that demonstrated my knowledge of health and medical issues was my brother-in-law severe allergic reaction. We went out for dinner and he unknowingly ate something that he was allergic to. We were out at a restaurant that didn't take reservations so we had been waiting over an hour for a table. After ordering, he soon started to itch and then started to swell. I told him it was important to get medical help right away because he could go into anaphylaxis. We got him to the hospital where he was treated. The knowledge I had gained through life experiences helped save my brother-in-law's life.
Text_Anxiety: Sometime its a little sad to think thatg my healtg us fading away and gettung concerns or news that somethjngay be wrong.
Text_TrustPhys: I believe that my primary care physician is Dana, who I've known for over 12 years. He is very thorough and professional and always has time to talk and ask questions. He never rushes me, which I appreciate.
Text_SubjectiveLit: My health care provider answers all of my questions and concerns thoroughly. If there is something I do not understand, he asks me if I want him to explain it to me in layman's terms.

Text_Numeracy: I went to the hospital as I was experiencing extreme pain on the right side of my abdomen, I didn't believe it was related to my stomach as my stomach was fine so I assumed it was my appendix and it was, it was removed.
Text_Anxiety: Uncertainties basically. I worry about the tests, what they would show, what the treatment may be etc. It's overall bad news when you're at the doctors.
Text_TrustPhys: He's a nice guy and he understands my needs because I train regularly and I'm the right weight for my size, but most of the doctors I've had in the past like to diagnose you and blast you with antibiotics so they can hurry off to the next patient.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I'm srety confident in my ability to do all the needed tasks for my health. We have a pretty good healthcare system in place and plenty of tools to help get through to doctors and nurses.

Text_Numeracy: I was watching a medical drama on TV. The doctor had a patient who was having trouble breathing. The doctor did a tracheostomy and inserted a tracheostomy tube into the patient to get air into their lungs. I thought to myself at first well that will work for now until we can do intubation where we can put a tube down into the lungs (which is more invasive), to get a better air exchange. But the Dr. seemed to think that would be all they needed. You don't normally do a tracheostomy for short term solution.
Text_Anxiety: no reply
Text_TrustPhys: I had a very good experience with my doctors. They're qualified and very responsible. They would never jeopardize your health for profit or something similar, just because they could.
Text_SubjectiveLit: respond to to degree do you feel you have the capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information and services needed to make appropriate health decisions in a few sentences

Text_Numeracy: During the COVID-19 pandemic, I took the initiative to educate myself on the different vaccines and the virus itself. I spent time researching credible sites on the vaccines, where they came from, how they worked, any potential side effects and so on. I also looked up information on the virus, such as how it was spread, and any treatments that were effective. Then I relayed the information I found in informative discussions with co-workers, friends and family.
Text_Anxiety: I think the most anxious part about visiting the doctor is that anytime they're giving you a medical examination they're trying to find something wrong. It's only the rare occasion when you go to the doctor and they say everything looks great, see you in a year! If you get bad news it could change your life so I think everyone has a little anxiety when visiting the doctor.
Text_TrustPhys: I think part of me distrusting physicians comes from horror films when patients have to run from their crazy doctors! I do not have a medical background so I am scared of not knowing.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel 90% capable of understanding health information and making decisions.I can answer almost all of my doctor and nurses' question without too much difficulty.

Text_Numeracy: A good example is when I was diagnosed with gastric reflux. My doctor allowed me to try an over the counter medication before using a prescription version. The over the counter version has smoothed my problem so well that I have not needed a prescriptions.
Text_Anxiety: I tend to feel nervous and excited when visiting doctors, unsure until they specifically tell me. When in situations where it becomes critical, I think more things go wrong than right with unexpected complications
Text_TrustPhys: I appreciate my doctor because I ask him many questions and he gives me answers he respects my questions and treats me with dignity and respect
Text_SubjectiveLit: I can understand the information given to me by healthcare professionals. They are able to answer questions that I may have on health information and services concerning my health. I can make the appropriate decisions concerning my health care.

Text_Numeracy: One experience that stands out for me was when I had to navigate a complex medication regimen after a significant health event. I took the initiative to research each prescription I was on, understanding the potential side effects and interactions between medications. This allowed me to engage meaningfully with my psychologist, discussing my concerns and ensuring that I was managing my health proactively. I also attended a health seminar on the importance of physical activity, which further reinforced my commitment to an active lifestyle as a cornerstone of overall well-being. This experience highlighted my dedication to staying informed about health and medical issues and how they affect my life.
Text_Anxiety: I don’t really experience feelings like anxiety, but I do recognize that visiting doctors can be a bit overwhelming at times. I’m mostly focused on ensuring that my prescriptions are managed properly and that I’m staying on track with my health goals. I suppose I might feel a little concerned about how the visit will go in terms of communication—I want to make sure I’m understood and that I get the right support for my health regimen. But overall, it's more about being diligent in my health journey than feeling anxious.
Text_TrustPhys: I don't currently have a primary care physician, but in general, my trust in doctors hinges on their expertise and communication skills. I tend to value healthcare providers who are knowledgeable and stay updated with the latest information about medications, especially since I take multiple prescriptions. Clear communication is crucial for me, as I want to understand how my medications and treatments affect my health. I've also noticed that a strong rapport with any healthcare provider can enhance my sense of trust, as it fosters a collaborative environment. However, my frequent visits to various specialists make it challenging to establish a consistent relationship, which can sometimes lead to feelings of uncertainty about their recommendations.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I believe I have a strong capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information and services. While I may not have a primary care physician at the moment, I actively engage in my health by visiting specialists regularly and staying informed about my prescription medications and their effects. My commitment to living in the best possible health drives me to research and understand the health information that is relevant to my situation, ensuring I can make well-informed decisions about my health.
